Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Photographs of the first explosion of an atomic bomb
Description#1: Album of photographs of the first detonation of an atomic bomb (the "Trinity test") in New Mexico in July, 1945. The album contains annotated photographs of the explosion at specific time intervals, as well as comparative photographs showing the size of the blast alongside various objects to demonstrate the scale of the explosion. Includes an introductory letter by Bartlett, a report on the test, and newspaper and magazine excerpts published after the test.
Source#1: Albert A. Bartlett Papers, box 9, Atomic West

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Postcard from Carlson to Lewis, 06 Jan 1942
Description#1: At the beginning of the letter, Louis Carlson states that he is ashamed that he had to hand write his letter, but thanked Nancy for her Christmas gift. Carlson noted that he began Officers Candidate School for the Quartermaster Branch of the military. While Carlson was attending Officers Candidate School, he was ranked as a cadet, but by March he will be ranked as a 2nd Lieutenant.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 05 Feb 1945
Description#1: In the V-Mail, Louis Carlson first asked about Nancy's new house. Carlson then states how his unit has been constantly moving, but for two weeks his unit is able to relax and take a break. From the sudden changes in weather, Carlson explains how the weather caused them to be working in 4 to 5 inches of mud.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 17 Feb 1943
Description#1: At the beginning of letter, Louis Carlson wrote how he enjoyed spending the weekend with Burnet, Nancy's cousin in Richmond, and that he was invited to return for a Sunday dinner. In addition to corresponding with Nancy and Juel, he has been writing with Nancy's sister, Becky. Since Carlson was in Virginia, he was hoping to meet Becky while he was still in the United States. Carlson ends his letter by stating there is a difference in weather compared to New York.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 04 Mar 1944
Description#1: After traveling to England, Louis Carlson writes in his V-Mail that the trip was comfortable and he did not have any problems. Once Carlson arrived in England, he was stationed in permanent barracks that were near a city. Carlson wrote that being near a city allowed him to visit historical locations and other cities.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 20 Apr 1945
Description#1: The letter begins by Louis Carlson stating it took him two weeks to write the letter, but he has been busy with his military assignments. From the interactions with the Germans, Carlson was assigned to translate German, since he took German while at college. When Carlson entered Germany, he wrote several comments about how impressive the Reichsautobahn was and how it was similar to American road systems. From traveling through Germany, Carlson describes the towns he saw and how the towns have been affected by the war. Carlson writes how he wished he was home and would love to spend time with Becky.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 12 May 1944
Description#1: The V-Mail begins by Louis Newbold apologizing to Nancy and Juel for not replying to their letters. Carlson then writes about his visit to London and his evening at his Officers Club.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 16 Jun 1944
Description#1: This letter begins by Louis Carlson thanking Nancy and Juel for taking the time to continue to write to him and that their letters gave him great joy. Carlson writes that his unit changed camps again and was near a town, but still did not have electricity or hot running water. Carlson then wrote how he also was frustrated with Willis Newbold Jr. who had not been responding to the letters he has received for over the past years. Carlson then states that he was been corresponding with Becky, which has caused him to develop feelings for her.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 20 Jun 1945
Description#1: The letter begins with Louis Carlson stating that he is happy that Nancy and Juel wrote to him and wonders about their new house. Carlson then questions Nancy about her house and then offers to help her with the garden. After Victory-Europe Day (V-E Day), Carlson wrote where he was in Germany and what his unit was transporting. He then wrote how the government's release point system, but he was several points short of being release. For the remainder of the letter Carlson writes how important correspondence has been for him.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 29 Jun 1944
Description#1: In this letter Louis Carlson describes his relationship with Nancy's sister, Becky, and wanted to know how Nancy felt about the relationship.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Postcard from Carlson to Lewis, 07 Jul 1945
Description#1: In the postcard Louis Carlson describes what he is planning on doing on his seven day leave. Carlson writes that he will stay in Carnes, Monte Carlo, and the Italian Alps.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter fron Carlson to Lewis, 03 Aug 1944
Description#1: This letter begins by Louis Carlson stating he was happy because he wrote to Nancy and Juel for the second time without receiving a reply letter. He then describes his trip while he traveled across on a Landing Ship Tank (LST) and landed on a beach. He states that American forces held a little section of France, but recently their movements have expanded further into France. Carlson ends the letter by asking Nancy to buy Becky something for her birthday and was wondering what Nancy thought about his relationship with Becky.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 23 Aug 1944
Description#1: The V-Mail began by Louis Carlson saying he has not forgotten about their friendship, but he has been busy since he arrived in England. Carlson describes the camps that he lived in and how the different camps had problems. As part of Carlson's duty he frequently traveled across England.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 25 Aug 1944
Description#1: This letter begins by Louis Carlson ensuring Nancy and Juel that he is ok, but has been very busy with the military expansion into Europe. He then ends his letter by describing his visit to Le Maris, a historic section of Paris, France.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 29 Aug 1944
Description#1: When Louis Carlson received Nancy's letter, he was pleased that she supported his decision that involved Becky, Nancy's sister. Since Becky has become involved in his life, he now views his actions in Europe as protecting her and she is the reason he is planning on returning. He wrote that even his mother would love to have Becky as a daughter-in-law. At the end of the V-Mail, Carlson told Nancy that within 24 hours, the newspapers report where his unit's operating location is.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 22 Sep 1944
Description#1: At the beginning of the letter, Louis Carlson explains that he received Nancy's letter, but he somehow lost it. He asks Nancy if she spent any money and if she spent more money than he gave her. While in Paris, France, Carlson bought Becky a ring, which was meant to be an engagement present. In addition to normal correspondence with Nancy and Becky, Carlson also wrote to Nancy's parents regarding his relationship with Becky. Carlson ends the letter by saying he was near Saint-Mihiel and could see the trenches from World War One.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Title#1: V-Mail from Carlson to Lewis, 29 Sep 1944
Description#1: In Carlson's V-Mail he thanks Nancy for helping him with his shopping and asks Nancy to provide a list of suggestions and an estimated cost. At the end of the V-Mail Carlson states that his unit has faced enemy resistance which caused transportation to slow down.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 03 Dec 1942
Description#1: This letter begins with Louis Carlson stating the difficulties that Willis Newbold Jr. has caused because he has not continued to correspond with his family. Carlson then asks Nancy and Juel to have dinner with his female cousin, to help cheer her up since her fiancée was killed in Africa. The letter ends by Carlson asking about how cities have changed because of the war.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Carlson to Lewis, 27 Dec 1944
Description#1: After receiving a Christmas box from Nancy and Juel, Louis Carlson writes how thankful he is and how much he loves his family and friends. Since it was Christmas time, Carlson wrote that he was unable to attend church and commented that he may not be able to attend church during this time of year. Carlson then describes how winter is affecting his living quarters and how the men are planning on celebrating the holiday.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 10 May 1941
Description#1: This item contains three different letters that a third party combined into a single one. In the first section of the letter, Willis Newbold wrote that he left Fort McClellan, Alabama to travel to Camp Forrest, Tennessee. During the trip they crossed the Wilson Lake several times and possibly tipped over in a ditch. In the other two sections of the letter, Newbold states they arrived at Camp Forrest and describes the condition of the camp and how they improved the camp while waiting for orders.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Description#1: This postcard has Willis Newbold Jr.'s address and a statement that he wrote two letters to Nancy and Juel that were currently being mailed to them.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 01 Sep 1942
Description#1: During this time Willis Newbold had worked as a temporary clerk in Washington D.C. In July Newbold determined that he wanted to return to his military unit and was again sworn in at the Washington Recruiting Office. Once sworn in, he was transferred to Fort Meade, Maryland to receive training. While at Fort Meade Newbold was placed in charge of four men before moving to Camp Forest, Tennessee. Newbold was then appointed as the Battalion Non-Commissioned Gas Officer, which carried the rank of sergeant and required Newbold to become a chemical warfare expert. This letter contains comments from a third party.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 26 Oct 1944
Description#1: The letter begins by Willis Newbold writing that he received Nancy and Juel's letter hours before strategic maneuvers that would provide weekend passes. He then describes the weather conditions that he faced while training near New York. At the end of the letter Newbold states that during his weekend liberty he will travel to Lynchburg, Virginia.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 27 Oct 1944
Description#1: At the beginning of the letter Willis Newbold wrote that he realized that his last letter was not clear about his trip to Lynchburg, Virginia. After describing how he had a difficult time writing the letter, he stated that he would call and let Nancy know that he received a pass that allowed him to travel to Lynchburg.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 01 Nov 1940
Description#1: This letter begins with a section that a third party added that provided information on how Willis Newbold enlisted in the army. Newbold began his letter by saying he has been busy and he has only been able to mail two letters so far. The letter continues to explain the weather, how the soldiers were transported, and military life. He comments that the camp was still under construction when began basic training.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Church Handout, 10 Nov 1940
Description#1: This church bulletin is from All Angels' Church, which was located on the 81st Street in New York. The bulletin shows the clergy and who was performing the services. The church also shows its support for the men who enlist into the military.

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 11 Nov 1940
Description#1: In a letter to his parents, Willis Newbold first comments on how the cold weather has affected them in their tents and how they spent the cold evenings in the mess halls. He then describes two of his tent mates, one who was changing the tent's electrical lighting and the other who was building a large table in the tent. Since his unit was finally settled, Newbold writes that he was thinking of starting a small newsletter and could possibly take the task of public relations for the 27th Division. The letter ends with several notes that were written by a third party.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 20 Nov 1940
Description#1: At the beginning of the letter, Newbold states that his unit has been frequently moving bases and that his commander assigned him as the company bugler. After explaining how he had to learn the correct bugle calls, he described his past military tasks and wrote about some difficulties living on a military base. Although he commented about the cold weather, he was excited that he was able to work on repairing an old WWI rifle range. Newbold ends by sending his love to his family and friends.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Collection Name: U.S. Military in War and Peace
Title#1: Letter from Newbold to Lewis, 23 Dec 1942
Description#1: In this letter to Nancy and Juel, Willis Newbold first comments how after a furlough the battalion immediately received training on how to complete a combat river crossing. While learning how to perform a river crossing, he wrote what the battalion did to complete the training exercise. Newbold lists what he received from several mail packages and thanks Nancy and Juel for their package of candy and puzzles. Newbold ends by apologizing for not writing back, but promises to write back in future letters.
Source#1: U.S. Military in War and Peace

Description#1: This note contains Willis Newbold's address and a statement wishing Merry Christmas to an unknown person.
